Biblical scholars recognize at least four different oral traditions that were joined in the Pentateuch. For example, at a superficial level the Yahwist tradition prefers the name Yahweh, while the Elohist tradition prefers the more generic and plural name Elohim. There is also the Priestly tradition which produced the creation story of Gen 1, while Gen 2 is Yahwist. The Priestly influence can also be seen in the story of Noah where there is some confusion as to whether there are two of every "kind," or whether 7 of the clean "kinds" were brought on board. It isn't clear whether it means 7 pairs or just 7. At any rate, the story of Noah is an intermixing of two oral traditions. The fourth tradition is the Deuteronomic tradition, which becomes apparent later in the Pentateuch.
 
 The point is that the two creation stories in Genesis came from different sources. Many scholars feel that they came from creation stories from ancient Sumer and the more recent Babylonian civilzation, both influential and mentioned in the Bible. The story of Noah was probably derived from the Sumerian epic of Gilgamesh.
 
 All in all, the stories are quite allegorical. It seems incredible that anyone could read the first two chapters of Genesis and conclude that they tell the same story, since they are contradictory beyond reconcilliation. Those who maintain that they are essentially the same story are afraid to read critically since to do so would challenge blind faith.
 
 Of course, Duo_Maxwell is correct. Whether allegorical or not, the Bible contradicts reality frequently. But it is our reality that is contradicted. To an unobservant, bronze age nomadic herdsman a grasshopper seemed to have 4 legs - they were a hated plague as well as a food source. Coneys (rabbits, hares) moved their mouth as if they were chewing cud - they are actually coprophagists eating their own first pass feces - definitely not cud. And bats are not fowl, even thought they fly.
 
 But the Bible isn't a scientific treatise. It is a collection of many oral traditions of a nomadic people.
